verses.text: After this, Absalom got himself a chariot and horses, and fifty men to run before him.
verses.comment: Describes Absalom adopting royal symbols. Closely follows Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: Absalom used to rise early and stand beside the road to the city gate. Whenever anyone had a dispute to bring before the king for judgment, Absalom would call out to him and ask, 'From what city are you?' And when he said, 'Your servant is from such and such a tribe of Israel,'
verses.comment: Maintains original dialogue style and intent.

verses.text: Absalom would say to him, 'See, your claims are good and right, but there is no one assigned by the king to hear you.'
verses.comment: Absalom undermines confidence in David's rule.

verses.text: Then Absalom would add, 'Oh, that I were made judge in the land! Then everyone with a dispute or case could come to me, and I would give him justice.'
verses.comment: Direct rendering of Hebrew; ‘give justice’ echoes legal context.

verses.text: Whenever someone approached to bow down to him, Absalom would reach out his hand, take hold of him, and kiss him.
verses.comment: Kissing expresses Absalom's feigned humility.

verses.text: Absalom did this to everyone of Israel who came to the king for judgment. In this way, Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel.
verses.comment: Phrase ‘stole the hearts’ is a literal translation from Hebrew.

verses.text: After four years, Absalom said to the king, 'Please let me go and pay my vow, which I made to the Lord, in Hebron.'
verses.comment: Many manuscripts say 'forty years,' but four is contextually and critically preferred.

verses.text: 'For your servant vowed a vow while I lived at Geshur in Aram, saying,
The king said to him, 'Go in peace.' So he set out and went to Hebron.
verses.comment: Phrase 'Go in peace' is commonly used as a dismissal in OT.

verses.text: But Absalom sent secret messengers throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, 'When you hear the sound of the trumpet, then say,
With Absalom went two hundred men from Jerusalem who were invited. They went in their innocence and did not know anything.
verses.comment: 'In their innocence' means unaware of Absalom’s intentions.

verses.text: While he was offering sacrifices, Absalom sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counselor, from his city Giloh. The conspiracy grew stronger, as the people with Absalom kept increasing.
verses.comment: Ahithophel’s defection marks seriousness of rebellion.

verses.text: A messenger came to David and said, 'The hearts of the men of Israel have gone after Absalom.'
verses.comment: Literal rendering, retaining Hebrew idiom 'gone after.'

verses.text: David said to all his servants who were with him at Jerusalem, 'Get up! Let’s flee! Otherwise, none of us will escape from Absalom. Hurry, or he will overtake us quickly, bring disaster on us, and strike the city with the sword.'
verses.comment: David’s urgency and imminent threat expressed.

verses.text: The king’s servants said to the king, 'Whatever my lord the king decides, your servants are ready to do.'
verses.comment: Affirms loyal service to David.

verses.text: So the king went out, and all his household followed him. But the king left ten concubines to keep the house.
verses.comment: David’s household details preserved as in Hebrew.

verses.text: The king went out, and all the people followed him. They stopped at the last house.
verses.comment: 'Last house'—literal translation; meaning last exit point.

verses.text: All his servants passed by him; all the Cherethites, all the Pelethites, and all the Gittites, six hundred men who had followed him from Gath, passed before the king.
verses.comment: Maintains names of elite groups, as in the original.

verses.text: The king said to Ittai the Gittite, 'Why should you also go with us? Go back and stay with the king. For you are a foreigner and also an exile from your own land.'
verses.comment: ‘Exile’ and ‘foreigner’ preserve original nuance.

verses.text: You only came yesterday. Should I make you wander with us, now that I go wherever I must go? Go back, and take your brothers with you, and may the Lord show you kindness and faithfulness.'
verses.comment: Preserves wordplay on ‘kindness and faithfulness’ (Hebrew: hesed ve’emet).

verses.text: But Ittai answered the king, 'As the Lord lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be—whether for death or for life—there your servant will be.'
verses.comment: Ittai’s oath echoes Ruth’s.

verses.text: David said to Ittai, 'Go and cross over.' So Ittai the Gittite crossed over, and all his men and the little ones with him.
verses.comment: ‘Little ones’ is literal; denotes children/family.

verses.text: All the people in the country wept with a loud voice as all the people passed by. The king crossed the brook Kidron, and all the people passed on toward the wilderness.
verses.comment: ‘Brook Kidron’ keeps geographical accuracy.

verses.text: And Zadok came also, and all the Levites with him, carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set down the ark of God, and Abiathar went up until all the people had finished passing out of the city.
verses.comment: ‘Went up’—possibly ascends or ministers.

verses.text: Then the king said to Zadok, 'Carry the ark of God back into the city. If I find favor in the Lord’s eyes, he will bring me back and let me see both it and his dwelling again.'
verses.comment: Faith in God’s providence preserved.

verses.text: But if he says, 'I have no pleasure in you,' then here I am—let him do with me whatever seems good to him.'
verses.comment: David submits himself to God's will.

verses.text: The king also said to Zadok the priest, 'Are you not a seer? Go back to the city in peace with your two sons, Ahimaaz your son, and Jonathan the son of Abiathar.'
verses.comment: 'Seer' (Hebrew 'ro’eh') means prophet.

verses.text: 'See, I will wait at the fords of the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me.'
verses.comment: 'Fords' denotes crossing-place of the river.

verses.text: Zadok and Abiathar carried the ark of God back to Jerusalem, and they remained there.
verses.comment: Simple, direct statement matching Hebrew sequence.

verses.text: David went up the ascent of the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went. He had his head covered and was walking barefoot. All the people who were with him covered their heads and went up, weeping as they went.
verses.comment: Details of mourning: head covered, barefoot; literal.

verses.text: And someone told David, 'Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom.' David prayed, 'O Lord, please turn the counsel of Ahithophel into foolishness.'
verses.comment: Prayer is direct quote in Hebrew.

verses.text: When David came to the summit, where God was worshiped, behold, Hushai the Archite came to meet him with his coat torn and dirt on his head.
verses.comment: 'Where God was worshiped'—literal; possibly site of sacrifice.

verses.text: David said to him, 'If you go on with me, you will be a burden to me.'
verses.comment: Literal, expresses practical concern.

verses.text: But if you return to the city and say to Absalom, “I will be your servant, O king; just as I was your father’s servant before, so I will now be your servant,” then you can help me by frustrating Ahithophel’s counsel.
verses.comment: Strategy for Hushai to be a double agent.

verses.text: Do you not have Zadok and Abiathar the priests with you there? So whatever you hear from the king’s house, tell it to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.
verses.comment: David’s instructions are direct.

verses.text: Their two sons are there with them, Ahimaaz son of Zadok, and Jonathan son of Abiathar. You shall send to me everything you hear by them.
verses.comment: The sons serve as couriers.

verses.text: So Hushai, David’s friend, came into the city as Absalom was entering Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Closes narrative transition.
